newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgo-French GSM operator Mobistar says sales soar.
newsitem.headline: Belgo-French GSM operator Mobistar says sales soar.

text.p: Belgian-French company Mobistar, which operates Belgium's second GSM mobile phone network, said on Monday it had signed up 68,000 clients four months after its launch -- 42,000 more than expected.
"This number strongly exceeds our initial forecast of 26,000," the company said in a statement. "Mobistar has now reached a sales rhythm initially expected for mid-1997," it said.
The statement quoted Mobistar Managing Director Bernard Ghillebaert as saying he was "very satisfied with the extremely fast start of Mobistar and with its operational results".
The statement said a survey carried out in late November and early December showed that 94 percent of Mobistar's clients were willing to recommend the service to friends and relatives.
Mobistar is owned 62 percent by France Telecom. Belgian data communications firm Telinfo NV has 10 percent and a group of eight other Belgian investors 28 percent.
Belgacom Mobile, which operates Belgium's first mobile phone service Proximus, had 409,000 GSM subscriptions by December 31.
Belgacom Mobile is 75-percent owned by Belgian state telephone operator Belgacom and 25-percent by AirTouch Communications Inc.
Belgacom Mobile spokesman Luc De Groote said he expected there to be 800,000 mobile phone users by the end of this year -- eight percent of the entire population.

De Groote told Reuters he expected two million mobile phone users by the year 2000 -- "as many as possible" of those from Belgacom Mobile. Mobistar has said it hopes to have 11 percent of the Belgian market by 2000.
Belgacom is 49.9 percent owned by a consortium including Ameritech, Singapore Telecom, Tele Danmark and three Belgian groups.
